Yet it was the central theme of his writing. Kind of hard to be a Marxist when you don't believe in the unifying theme.
 
 Correct me if am I wrong, but Marx wrote heavily about the transition from capitalistic, industrialized economies where the worker had little power over the elite classes and how these countries would eventually move over to a classless society ruled by a democracy of the worker where everything was stated owned. How can you be a Marxist when you are solidly for private corporations, capitalism and the class system?
 
 
 They weren't. The USSR was not Communist. People would have liked to believe they were, but having a class society, with a dictatorship more or less eliminates them from the caterogry.

 
 The USSR was socialist, which is 100% Marxist. "The State and Revolution", Lennisn blueprint for the Soviet Union, was little more than a paraphrase of Marx's work. 
 
 Since marx was essentially the inventor of Socialism, it is not at all unreasonable to say that socialist ideas are marxist. The fact that the powers that be prefer to stop at the 5th stage as opposed to moving to the 6th stage not only does not make the thinking any less marxist, it was actually PREDICTED by Marx in what is unquestionably the most famous passage from the Communist Manifesto...his description of the transition from stage 5 (socialism) to stage 6 (communism):
 
 
When, in the course of development, class distinctions have disappeared, and all production has been concentrated in the hands of a vast association of the whole nation, the public power will lose its political character. Political power, properly so called, is merely the organized power of one class for oppressing another. If the proletariat during its contest with the bourgeoisie is compelled, by the force of circumstances, to organize itself as a class; if, by means of a revolution, it makes itself the ruling class, and, as such, sweeps away by force the old conditions of production, then it will, along with these conditions, have swept away the conditions for the existence of class antagonisms and of classes generally, and will thereby have abolished its own supremacy as a class. In place of the old bourgeois society, with its classes and class antagonisms, we shall have an association in which the free development of each is the condition for the free development of all.

 
 
 What he is calling for here is a violent revolution of the proletariat to once and for all seize power. He also saw this as an inevitable event, but not necessarily a planned one, because the bourgeoisie would never allow the proletariat to amass the power necessary to violently overthrow them if it was predicatable that they would do so. 
 
 So, according to Marx, pretty much the inevitable trasnsition from socialism to communism involves a violent overthrow...the end of political power and the end of the bourgeoisie. At the same time, the transition from capitalism to socialism requires the assistance of the bourgeoisie and whatever political power that may be in order to succeed. 
 
 What that tells me is that not only are there an awful lot of marxists out there who do not necessarily consider the destruction of classes and corporation to be a critical aspect of MArxism, but that Marx himself expected as much since nobody willingly works toward their own destruction.

Yeah, I don't doubt those two options. The question is can you slowly get rid of the military thus spread out the loss over a few years. 
 
 In reality you only need to clean up a few things to get out budget in line. People complain about "pork", NASA, and some agencies but these are all pocket change compared to the big four:
 
 Department of Defense: 658 billion
 Department of Health and Human Services: 678.8 billion
 Social Security Administration: 593.1 billion
 Interest on T-bills: 221.5 billion
 
 But since we are on the topic now, lets share a little bit from the Comptroller which you might find interesting:
 (these are clips from a presentation last year)
 
 GAO's simulations show that balancing the budget in 2040 could require actions as large as
 Cutting total federal spending by 60 percent or
 Raising federal taxes to 2 times today's level
 Added later was: Faster Economic Growth Can Help, but It Cannot Solve the Problem
 
 The United States may be the only superpower, but compared to most other OECD countries on selected key economic, social, and environmental indicators, on average, the U.S. ranks 16 out of 28

Yeah, I don't doubt those two options. The question is can you slowly get rid of the military thus spread out the loss over a few years. 

 
 I think that whether we can spread it out over several years to lessen the blow depends on when we start. When it comes to economic planning, the US is not real big on forward planning. We could have started a couple decades ago and by now we would be at the point where we have a reasonably sized military, a sustainable fiscal outlook, and the pain would have been barely noticable.
 
 Today, we have our treasury secretary running to congress every year or 2 to explain to them that if they don't raise the debt ceiling the Government will become insolvent and be forced to cease operation. If you look at government spending as a percentage of just about any data set, you see that reductions in federal spending will result in recession. Steep enough reductions will result in depression. The Federal governments spending is BY FAR the dominate force in our economy, and having a nation whose primary occupation is the maintenance and funding of their government is simply not sustainable.
 
 Personally, I think the discussion of "sweeping changes vs gradual changes" is moot because it certainly appears that in the end the path we will choose is "No changes". We will just keep doing what we are doing until we reach a crisis point and by then it will be too late.

All government employees are lining their pockets at your expense. Who do you think pays their salary?
 
 A good government will be small.

 
 They aren't looking for a bonus based on the denial of services, however.
